awd_titl_txt: Tests of Independence Conditions Using a Discontinuously Distributed Covariate
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop statistical tests for selection on observables and validity of instrumental variables assumption necessary for identifying causal effects under mild restrictions on structural functions. Existing methods impose other stringent restrictions to test identifying assumptions. This test will avoid such stringent restrictions by exploiting discontinuities that arise in the distribution of unobservable in the model conditional on the treatment variable as well as the existence of another covariate. The testing procedure will also exploit continuity of the structural functions in this special covariate and monotonicity of the structural function in one of the unobservable variables. The test is applicable to continuous or discrete treatment without instrumental variables in the context of non-parametric, non-separable, single equation model. 

This research will also develop a procedure for testing validity of instrumental variable for continuously distributed endogenous treatment variable in the context of a nonparametric triangular model. For both problems, the models can be nonparametric and non-separable in the unobserved heterogeneity, as well as settings with more stringent parametric or semi-parametric restrictions. The research results will encourage other researchers to identify such settings, and thus extend the range of empirical problems in which identification conditions can be tested. The results of this research will improve the ability to establish causal relationships, hence improve economic policy making, policy evaluation, and economic efficiency generally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Economists are often interested in the effect of one variable, which often is called treatment, on an outcome of interest, while holding everything else constant. In some cases a double blind, randomized controlled trial can be designed to quantify such effects. For many questions relevant to economists this cannot be done, however. With observational data, we often have to make assumptions, like selection on observables/unconfoundedness assumption or availability of an instrumental variable, to quantify such an effect. The two projects contained in the award proposed to provide testing procedures for these assumptions under mild conditions on the data generating processes.The common element in the way we attack each of these questions is the availability of a covariate that has a discontinuity in its distribution at a known point. This variable is not the treatment variable. Nevertheless, this variable should be relevant for the question of interest. Settings in which a covariate has a discontinuous distribution with a known point of discontinuity have already been found in the literature. The purpose of the research proposed was to identify additional settings which give rise to observable variables with discontinuous distributions; to illustrate existence of empirical research problems in which such variables can be used to test identification conditions, and thus, significantly extend the range of empirical applications where identification assumptions can be tested under mild conditions on structural functions; and to establish how such settings can be exploited.

All of these goals have been achieved. The results of the research on the first project supported by the award is presented in my paper ``A test of the selection on observables assumption using a discontinuously distributed covariate", Journal of Econometrics,Volume 226:2, 2022, p. 423-450, with U. Khalil. This paper: provides novel testing procedures for the selection on observables assumption; analyzes the large and small sample behavior of the test statistic that I believe will be used by empirical researchers; provides empirical scenarios for which data are available and in which this testing procedure can be applied. Finally, the paper implements this test with an empirical application. It is well known that low birth weight and other complications at birth are linked to significant health costs especially during infancy and early childhood, and that a healthy intrauterine environment is considered to be of critical importance for positive birth outcomes. To ease these concerns the U.S. government operates : the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC). The objective of this program is to improve birth outcomes of low-income pregnant mothers, and provides food supplements, nutrition education, and access to health services. Researchers have been interested in evaluating the effectiveness of this large federal program. Most of this research was done using a selection on observables/unconfoundedness assumption on WIC participation. This literature finds treatment effects on average birth weight ranging from no effect to gains upwards of 60g (Bitler, Hotz, Imbens and Mitnik (2005); Figlio, Hamersma and Roth (2009)). Using the statistical testing procedure developed in the first part of the project my co-author and I tested the validity of of this assumption in this context. We implement the testing procedure using different sets of control variables. When we only control for demographic information of parents aswell as birth order, information on prenatal care, gestation and linear controls for smoking three months prior to the pregnancy as well as in the first two trimesters with a flexible specification of how these affect birth outcomes, we find the WIC participation fails to satisfy the unconfoundedness assumption. Then we implement the test with a wider variety of controls including parental age, race, education, marital status, various interactions between the demographic variables of the mother, measures of prenatal care, risk factors during the current pregnancy, and whether she had a poor outcome for a previous pregnancy, a cubic polynomial in prepregnancy BMI, non-parametric controls for gestation, and flexible controls for mother’s smoking behavior across trimesters during pregnancy similar to the one used first by Almond, Chay and Lee (2005). We find that when the set of controls is extended this way WIC participation variable does seem to satisfy the unconfoundedness assumption (i.e. we cannot reject that it satisfies this assumption).

For both parts of the project, I was able to devise statistical procedures that can be easily understood and implemented by applied researchers. I believe having testing procedures that can be implemented using existing STATA packages is an advantage for applied economists. The statistical testing procedures I devised can be implemented using existing STATA packages.

A significant achievement in the second part of the project is the extension of Hoeffding decomposition for U-statistics in which the kernel depends on the sample size to to third order U-statistics. It seems to be a new result. 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/13/2023
Modified by: Nese Yildiz
